articles.headline: A Simple Equation: More Education = More Income
articles.snippet: The United States trails nearly all other industrialized nations when it comes to educational equality, and it shows in income inequality.
articles.abstract: The United States trails nearly all other industrialized nations when it comes to educational equality, and it shows in income inequality.
articles.lead_paragraph: Imagine if the United States government taxed the nation’s one-percenters so that their post-tax share of the nation’s income remained at 10 percent, roughly where it was in 1979. If the excess money were distributed equally among the rest of the population, in 2012 every family below that very top tier would have gotten a $7,105 check.

articles.headline: Obama, in Speech on ISIS, Promises Sustained Effort to Rout Militants
articles.snippet: President Obama expanded the campaign against ISIS to include airstrikes in Syria and more American advisers in Iraq, but he sought to distinguish the new action from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: President Obama expanded the campaign against ISIS to include airstrikes in Syria and more American advisers in Iraq, but he sought to distinguish the new action from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday authorized a major expansion of the military campaign against rampaging Sunni militants in the Middle East, including American airstrikes in Syria and the deployment of 475 more military advisers to Iraq. But he sought to dispel fears that the United States was embarking on a repeat of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

articles.headline: From Kurdistan to Texas, Scots Spur Separatists
articles.snippet: From Catalonia to Kurdistan, nationalist and separatist movements in Europe and beyond are watching the Scottish independence referendum closely.
articles.abstract: From Catalonia to Kurdistan, nationalist and separatist movements in Europe and beyond are watching the Scottish independence referendum closely.
articles.lead_paragraph: STEENOKKERZEEL, Belgium — For Kurt Ryon, the mayor of Steenokkerzeel, a Flemish village 10 miles northeast of Brussels, watching the Scottish independence campaign in the final days before the referendum is like watching a good soccer match. “They were losing for the first half and most of the second half,” he said, “but now we’re in the 85th minute and they could be winning.”

articles.headline: Detroit’s Bankruptcy Deal Hinges on 2 Banks
articles.snippet: An innovative type of loan in 2005 now stands as a roadblock to Detroit’s exit from bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: An innovative type of loan in 2005 now stands as a roadblock to Detroit’s exit from bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Syncora Guarantee, Detroit’s most vociferous adversary in bankruptcy, is close to a breakthrough settlement with the city, but before it can close the deal it must resolve a related dispute with two big banks, Bank of America and UBS.

articles.headline: With Apple Pay and Smartwatch, a Privacy Challenge
articles.snippet: Apple faces two threats: one from hackers looking for ways to steal financial information, and another from regulators interested in ensuring that information gleaned from health monitoring devices stays private.
articles.abstract: Apple faces two threats: one from hackers looking for ways to steal financial information, and another from regulators interested in ensuring that information gleaned from health monitoring devices stays private.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one has considered Apple a serious data company, until now.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Cereals Begin to Lose Their Snap, Crackle and Pop
articles.snippet: The cereal business has been in steady decline for a decade as consumers opt for healthier options or food easier to eat on the run in the morning.
articles.abstract: The cereal business has been in steady decline for a decade as consumers opt for healthier options or food easier to eat on the run in the morning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cereal, that bedrock of the American breakfast, has lost some of its snap, crackle and pop.

articles.headline: Alibaba Is Bringing Luxury, Fast, to China’s Middle Class
articles.snippet: The Internet giant is bringing e-commerce into the homes of China’s rapidly expanding middle class.
articles.abstract: The Internet giant is bringing e-commerce into the homes of China’s rapidly expanding middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cold day in April, a group of New Zealand fishermen set out to harvest 50,000 large oysters from the waters of the South Pacific.

articles.headline: Microsoft Sees More Than Fun in a Game Like Minecraft
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that gaming is central to many people’s lives, serving as an engaging mode of entertainment or merely a time killer.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s acquisition of Minecraft would be an acknowledgment that gaming is central to many people’s lives, serving as an engaging mode of entertainment or merely a time killer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Parents like Minecraft because it can be a creative outlet for their children. Teachers like the game because it can bring lessons to life. And Microsoft likes the game so much that the tech giant wants to buy Minecraft’s parent company for more than $2 billion.

articles.headline: New Military Campaign Extends a Legacy of War
articles.snippet: President Obama on Wednesday night may have ensured that he will pass his successor a volatile and incomplete war, just as he inherited one when he took office.
articles.abstract: President Obama on Wednesday night may have ensured that he will pass his successor a volatile and incomplete war, just as he inherited one when he took office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In ordering a sustained military campaign against Islamic extremists in Syria and Iraq, President Obama on Wednesday night effectively set a new course for the remainder of his presidency and may have ensured that he would pass his successor a volatile and incomplete war, much as his predecessor left one for him.

articles.headline: Struggling to Gauge ISIS Threat, Even as U.S. Prepares to Act
articles.snippet: As President Obama prepares to send the United States on what could be a yearslong military campaign, American intelligence agencies have concluded that the group poses no immediate threat to the United States.
articles.abstract: As President Obama prepares to send the United States on what could be a yearslong military campaign, American intelligence agencies have concluded that the group poses no immediate threat to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The violent ambitions of the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria have been condemned across the world: in Europe and the Middle East, by Sunni nations and Shiite ones, and by sworn enemies like Israel and Iran. Pope Francis joined the call for ISIS to be stopped.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and Mark Landler
